ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course instructors were very hands-off, and the class was mostly structured and organized by the TA. Individual classes were generally led by visiting lecturers.
Professors Spalding and Terrell didn't really teach -- the class was all based on guest lectures (some in person, many over Skype).

This was the first time FES offered such a course. I think Elliott did a wonderful job of making it happen. However, it should have more administrative support. I pulled information from the class and speakers, but wonder how well other students appreciated the topics. It was good to get exposure to the modeling software used by timber manager, but I feel like we had to cover a lot in a sort time, with limited isntruction.

Not quite fair to judge this course on same scale as others, considering we came up with it and designed it rather haphazardly. Kudos to elliott for stringing this together with little help. FES needs more exposure to growth and yield modeling. it's embarrassing that we needed to create this course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The TA did an incredible job organizing and planning the course, and was able to bring in a lot of really interesting guest lecturers.
exposure to a critical subject matter otherwise untaught at FES!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: This was a pilot course so understandably a little disorganized. It would have helped to adjust the structure a little - sometimes someone talking through spreadsheets over Skype was not very helpful. Would have been great to get to use Woodstock and not just FVS. Also would have been good to discuss sustainable G&Y principles alongside the financials, a couple of speakers seemed quite removed from sustainability, did not seem to really care about conservation.

The course didn't have the resources that it needed to be truly successful. None of the instructors had enough experience with the material and programs used to clearly instruct students in their use. There were a lot of technical hiccups throughout the course, as a result.

Instruction on the tools the class was supposed to use. It was difficult to work with and integrate FVS and Excel etc. with no prior experience and under the constraints of such a short period of time. Also, the course could benefit from more clearly linking the guest lectures together and trying to bring the lecturers into New Haven instead of doing things over Skype.

Deborah Spalding is a wonderful person and incredible teacher WHEN SHE HAS TIME. Given her other career obligations, she SHOULD NOT be teaching. I feel very strongly that giving her teaching responsibilities is robbing students of a learning opportunity. She is not nearly as available as effective as she is capable of being as a teacher.
Designated faculty who knows what theyre doing in G&Y models. earlier coordination with guest speakers.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Would help to have the class more formalized to include lab time to run things through with the TA.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm very interested in Forest and Ecosystem Finance, so knowing how to estimate forest growth and value over time, and incorporate that value into financial modeling is critical.

If I'm planning to go into the field of forestry, regardless of what approach, I'm going to need to know some growth and yield modeling. Even just enough to know the right questions to ask. THis course started me on the right trajectory, but still a long way to go...

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To gain a basic understanding of the tools used for financial and growth and yield modeling of forest stands.
To learn more modeling skills and to learn about how modeling informs management decisions.
see answers above. this is a huge hole in the MF curriculum

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not really. I expected to gain a deeper understanding of the programs we discussed in class, but the expertise necessary to provide that education doesn't really exist at FES at this time.
Maybe not to the full extent, but to some extent.

It gave me some exposure. Not enough, but better than nothing. I now know more about what I DONT know, which is helpful. And I also am aware of some resources to go hunt down when I do need to know more about G&Y.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
helpful to learn with a partner

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take Forest & Ecosystem Finance before
Until this class is seen as a priority by the Forestry School and given the resources and staffing necessary to make it successful, it probably isn't the most valuable use of students' class time.

See if you can find out what changes have been made. This was the first year this class was taught so there were a lot of kinks to work out. The concepts covered in this course are valuable and the instructors are committed to improving it, so keep it on your radar!

This is critical knowledge for working in forestry / conservation. Data will play an increasingly significant role in land management. You may not want to be the Woodstock grunt, but you should know enough about it to ask the right questions. Get in to this course and get your hands dirty.
